item.title: The collapsed state of position measurement
item.author: hfwang132@gmail.com (hfwang132)
item.description:
Common sense tells us that an actual position measurement will not produce a delta function, as the delta function itself is pathological. So what should the collapsed state of an actual position measurement look like?

TL;DR:

Let the wave function of the system to be measured be $\varphi(x)$, then the collapsed wave function is:

$\varphi^{(q)}(x) = \mathcal{A}\psi(q-gx) \varphi(x)$

where $\psi(x)$ is the initial wave function of the instrument’s pointer. $q$ is the reading of the instrument’s pointer. $g$ is the coupling strength between the instrument and the system to be measured. $\begin{aligned} \mathcal{A} = \left[\int_\mathbb{R}\psi(q-gx) \varphi(x)\right]^{-1} \end{aligned}$ is the appropriate normalization constant.

item.title: The difference between quantum entanglement and classical correlation, and the Quantum Measurement Problem
item.author: hfwang132@gmail.com (hfwang132)
item.description:
Many physicists use an example to explain quantum entanglement to the public:

Imagine you have two boxes, one containing pizza and the other a burger. Before opening the boxes, you cannot know what is inside. Alice and Bob each take a box and move to distant locations. When Alice opens her box, she instantly knows what is in Bob’s box far away.

This example must be wrong… because it doesn’t involve quantum mechanics at all.

item.title: POVM: a brief introduction
item.author: hfwang132@gmail.com (hfwang132)
item.description:
Projection Measurement

Traditionally, a measurement, in the sense of Von Neumann, is a series of projection operators. By performing spectral decomposition on the self-adjoint operator corresponding to the observable, denoted as $ O = \sum_i \lambda_i |\varphi_i\rangle\langle\varphi_i| $, we obtain these projection operators $ |\varphi_i\rangle\langle\varphi_i| $. This part is well-known to students who have studied elementary quantum mechanics.

Besides the Von Neumann measurement, there is a more general type of measurement called Generalized Measurements or Positive Operator Valued Measures (POVMs).
